item.title: AskPoker.ai Log #3: When Perfect Tech Meets Messy Reality
item.description:
Sometimes the biggest technical breakthroughs happen in the same week as your most frustrating creative blocks. This week I solved major backend issues that had been plaguing AskPoker for months, then promptly got humbled by the seemingly simple task of making a TikTok video.

Technical Wins: The Foundation Finally Works

Expresso Integration Complete

The backend now fully supports 3-player Spin & Go tournaments (called “Expresso” in France). This was the strategic pivot I mentioned in dev log #2 - focusing on a format I actually understand rather than chasing global cash game markets I don’t play.

The solver handles 3-player dynamics properly now. Short stacks, push-fold situations - all the elements that make these tournaments strategically unique are captured in the analysis.

Range Handling Rewrite

Remember the sampling bottleneck from last week? The one that made turn and river analysis painfully slow? Fixed.

I rewrote the core range handling system to maintain explicit range objects throughout the entire calculation pipeline. Instead of the hacky sampling approach that was creating computational bottlenecks, the solver now tracks hand probabilities properly at every decision point.

The Hidden Bug

While rewriting the range system, I discovered something embarrassing: the old method had an off-by-one error that was subtly affecting all calculations. Not game-breaking, but enough to skew some strategic recommendations.

This is why I’m glad I found this during the rewrite rather than after publishing hundreds of analyses with slightly wrong math. The new system is both faster and more accurate.

The technical foundation is now solid. Turn and river analysis works. Complex tournament situations get proper treatment. I can generate comprehensive hand breakdowns without computational constraints.

The Video Content Reality Check

With the backend working, I turned to the main challenge: creating video content for TikTok and other platforms.

The AI Conversion Experiment

My first attempt was logical but naive: automatically convert the blog posts I’d written into video scripts using AI.

The results were terrible. The AI would generate robotic voiceovers paired with generic poker visuals that had no engagement factor whatsoever. Even when the strategic content was accurate, the presentation was so boring that no one would watch past the first few seconds.

Written content and video content serve different purposes. Blog posts can dive deep into nuanced strategic concepts. Videos need immediate hooks and clear, simple messages. The formats aren’t interchangeable.

Manual Conversion Overwhelm

Next, I tried manually adapting the written content. I printed out blog posts, started breaking them into video segments, thinking about visual elements, transitions, hooks…

Two hours in, I was overwhelmed. The amount of creative decisions required for each piece of content was staggering. Which hands to showcase? What visual style? How to structure the narrative? What’s the hook in the first 3 seconds?

I realized I was trying to become a video creator overnight when I’m fundamentally a developer. After two days of this, I gave up on the blog conversion approach entirely.

The Pivot to Simplicity

Instead of complex content adaptation, I moved to the simplest possible format: direct app demonstration.

The process became straightforward:

  1. Play actual Expresso tournaments and record the sessions
  2. Take interesting hands from those sessions
  3. Record myself asking AskPoker about those hands
  4. Create an AI avatar using HeyGen with ElevenLabs voice narration
  5. Edit everything together in Kapwing

This format showcases the product directly without requiring complex storytelling or educational frameworks. Users see exactly what the experience looks like.

The Uncanny Valley Problem

I was happy with the first video I produced. The demonstration was clear, the analysis was accurate, and the production quality looked professional.

Then I showed it to my brothers.

“The voice feels too unnatural,” they said immediately. “It’s obviously AI, and people just won’t want to watch this.”

This created a dilemma. I wanted the “full AI feeling” for the content - using AI to generate the avatar, voice, and even some of the script. It felt thematically consistent with building an AI poker coach.

But if the AI-generated presentation makes content unwatchable, it defeats the purpose entirely.

Platform Compliance Issues

When I posted the video on TikTok, it got restricted for not respecting their content policies. I need to investigate what specifically triggered this - was it the AI avatar, the poker content, or something else entirely?

This adds another layer of complexity. Even if I solve the authenticity problem, I still need to navigate platform-specific rules about AI-generated content, gambling-adjacent topics, and promotional material.

Facebook ads present another compliance hurdle. Getting approval for poker-related content with AI elements might require careful positioning and multiple iterations.

The Deeper Lesson

This week highlighted an interesting contrast: technical problems versus creative problems.

Rewriting the range handling system was straightforward. The requirements were clear, the success criteria were measurable, and the solution was mostly a matter of careful implementation.

Creating engaging video content feels impossibly subjective. What makes one video engaging while another falls flat? How do you balance authenticity with production efficiency? When does AI enhancement become a liability?

Having a working product doesn’t automatically translate to compelling marketing content. The skills required are completely different, and the feedback loops are much longer and harder to interpret.

Next Week’s Strategy

Natural Voice Experiments

I need to test whether recording my own voice produces better results than the AI-generated narration. This means giving up some of the “full AI” aesthetic I was pursuing, but if it makes the content more engaging, that’s the right trade-off.

Compliance Deep Dive

Understanding exactly what triggered the TikTok restriction and what Facebook requires for ad approval. This might involve creating multiple versions of content with different approaches to stay within platform guidelines.

The Bigger Question

When to push AI boundaries versus when to embrace human elements? Maybe the best AI-powered business isn’t the one that uses AI everywhere, but the one that applies AI strategically where it adds the most value.

For AskPoker, that might mean AI for the core strategic analysis (where computational power matters) and human elements for content creation (where authenticity and relatability matter).

Next Week Preview

Testing whether authentic presentation trumps polished AI production, and diving deep into content platform compliance requirements.

item.title: AskPoker.ai Log #2: Building a Content Engine and Finding My Market
item.description:
Week 2 of building AskPoker.ai in public. This week: technical progress, content creation infrastructure, and a strategic market pivot.

Technical Progress: Building the Data Pipeline

Last week’s experiments made it clear I needed better data from my solver to create meaningful content. So I built a comprehensive evaluation function:

type EvalReport struct {
    ActionEVs []float32  // Expected value for each possible action
    Equity    float32    // Current hand equity
    EQRs      []float32  // Equity realization by action
    AvgPolicy []float64  // Solver's recommended action frequencies
    AvgEquity float32    // Average equity across opponent range
}

This gives me everything needed to explain why a play is optimal, not just what to do. I wrote a script that runs this for every decision point in a hand, creating a complete strategic narrative.

The Bottleneck

Here’s where past shortcuts caught up with me. Generating game states by sampling from subgames is painfully slow. Why? A month ago, I took a shortcut in how I handle range distributions. Instead of maintaining explicit range objects with hand probabilities, I used a simpler approach that now makes sampling computationally expensive.

The fix is straightforward ‚Äì properly maintain range objects throughout the calculation. But it means rewriting a chunk of the solver infrastructure. For now, turn and river analysis is essentially broken, limiting me to flop-only content.

I decided to defer this fix. Why spend days on technical debt when I still need to validate whether anyone wants this product?

Content Creation Engine: From Data to Articles

Instead of perfecting the solver, I built a content generation pipeline:

  1. Data Generation: Run EvalHand for each decision point
  2. AI Analysis: Feed each situation to an LLM for strategic interpretation
  3. Outline Creation: Combine solver data + manual context ‚Üí LLM creates article outline
  4. Human Review: I review and adjust the outline
  5. Draft Generation: LLM writes the first draft
  6. Final Edit: Human polish and fact-checking

The process works. I published two deep-dive analyses:

  • Montenegro’s $444k pot breakdown
  • $100k pocket tens analysis

Images are still manual (screenshots, generated images), and there’s an annoying OpenGraph bug to fix, but the core pipeline produces solid content. Each piece takes about 2-3 hours from data to published article.

Strategic Market Pivot: Narrowing Focus

This week forced a reality check on my market ambitions.

Original vision: Target US/global cash games ‚Äì the biggest poker market. These games typically run 7-9 players with varying stack sizes.

The problems:

  • My solver only handles 5-max games
  • I don’t actually play these formats (French platforms are segregated)
  • Technical complexity scales exponentially with more players
  • I’m building for a market I don’t understand

New direction: French 3-player Spin & Go tournaments.

Yes, it’s a smaller market. But consider:

  • 3 players instead of 9 (dramatically simpler to solve)
  • Short stacks (less strategic complexity)
  • Most popular format in France
  • I actually play this format daily

This feels like a retreat, but it’s strategic. Better to build something that works for a market I understand than to fail chasing a larger opportunity.

The “We’ll Expand Later” Trap

I’m aware of the risk. Countless startups say “we’ll expand later” and become trapped in their initial niche. Their product-market fit becomes so specific that expansion requires starting over.

But poker might be different. The core challenge isn’t teaching French players different rules ‚Äì it’s getting anyone to trust AI coaching. If I can prove French players will take strategic advice from an AI, that psychological validation should transfer across markets. The technical details (game formats, stack sizes) are engineering problems. Trust is the real barrier.

Next Focus: TikTok Experimentation

The blog posts are live but not promoted ‚Äì they’re raw material for the next experiment. This week I’m pivoting to TikTok content creation. Poker strategy performs well in short-form video, and it’s where my target audience actually spends time.

The plan: Transform blog analyses into bite-sized video content. Test what resonates. Learn what hooks work. Then scale what succeeds.

Looking Ahead

Week 2 taught me to embrace constraints. My solver can’t handle everything, so I’ll focus on what it can. The global market is too broad, so I’ll start with France. Perfect technical solutions can wait until after market validation.

Next week: Results from TikTok experiments and the eternal question ‚Äì when do I fix that sampling bug?

What would you build for your local market first? Let me know on Twitter or Discord.

item.title: AskPoker.ai Log #1: Reality Check and Pivot to Concierge MVP
item.description:
AskPoker.ai Week 1: Reality Check and Pivot to Concierge MVP

This week I learned some hard truths about my assumptions building AskPoker.ai. Time for radical honesty about what’s working and what isn’t.

For context, AskPoker.ai is my attempt to build a conversational AI poker coach that gives recreational players instant, solver-backed analysis of their hands. Instead of wrestling with complex software like PioSOLVER, players can just describe their hand in plain English and get clear strategic advice. I’ve been working on this for about 6 months, and this is my first public update on the journey. You can read more about the original vision in my announcement post.

What I Tried: Forum Engagement Experiment

My plan was simple: test demand by answering poker hands on Reddit and 2+2 with AskPoker analysis. Use the tool to generate insights, then sign responses with “made with askpoker.ai” to see if people were interested in the platform.

The goal was to validate the core value proposition while driving some early traffic. What I found instead was a masterclass in why assumptions need real-world testing.

Hard Truths Discovered

1. The Product Isn’t Ready

Table size limitation: My backend solver only handles 5-max tables, not the 6+ player tables common in most online games. When users post hands from full ring games, the solver has no data, so the LLM just improvises answers based on general poker knowledge.

I knew this was a constraint going in, but experiencing it in practice hit different. I now understand I must solve this limitation eventually (though interestingly, in the French market where 5-max cash games dominate, this might not be as critical).

Scope mismatch: I built the tool to analyze single decisions (“Should I call this river bet?"), but users want comprehensive hand reviews. They want to know where their decisions went wrong across multiple streets, not just get advice on one spot.

Insufficient backend data: The solver gives me the optimal action, but lacks the rich context needed for proper explanations - full ranges, equity calculations, expected value, fold equity. Without this data, the LLM fills in gaps with educated guesses that sometimes sound confident but are wrong.

Basic bugs: Simple things like currency-to-blind conversion. I expected the LLM to handle this automatically when calling the backend, but it doesn’t.

2. Market Reality Check

Forum fragmentation: Even active communities like 2+2 and Reddit aren’t exactly buzzing with activity. There’s discussion, but it’s not the vibrant marketplace of poker questions I had imagined.

French market gap: I found essentially no active French poker discussion platforms. This surprised me - I expected at least some local communities.

User behavior insight: Players consume more content (YouTube, training sites) than they engage in forum discussions. This suggests my marketing approach needs to meet users where they actually spend time, not where I assumed they’d be.

3. The Concierge MVP Reality Check

Here’s where brutal honesty matters: my initial assessment was too rosy.

Actual results: About 75% of my responses were ignored, ~15% got genuine positive responses from users (actual replies thanking me for the analysis), and ~10% were called out for containing errors where the LLM had hallucinated explanations.

Reddit truth: People might not always give positive feedback when you help them, but they never let wrong analysis slide. Every mistake gets caught and corrected, often harshly.

Key insight: Demand absolutely exists for expert-level analysis in accessible language, but the quality bar is unforgiving. There’s no room for “pretty good” when giving strategic advice.

The Pivot: From Product to Process

Why Concierge MVP Makes Sense

The product is too broken for self-service user testing, but the manual approach validates something crucial: the core value proposition works when executed correctly.

More importantly, I need to answer a fundamental question: Are recreational players ready to trust an AI coach? This is about more than just technical capability - it’s about user psychology and market readiness.

While I’m confident I can solve the technical issues given enough time, creating trust is a different challenge entirely. This requires marketing and communication skills that aren’t in my natural wheelhouse, making validation even more critical.

My new process: users message me via email or Discord for hand analysis. I use the backend tool to generate insights, then manually refine and explain the analysis. This creates a controlled environment to test whether players accept AI-driven coaching when it’s delivered thoughtfully.

New Strategy: Content-Led Growth

Blog foundation: Generate poker-specific content using the LLM+solver combination. This content becomes source material for TikTok scripts and other marketing efforts - creating a scalable content system.

TikTok expansion: Meet users where they actually are, not in forums. Poker content performs well on TikTok, and the format suits quick hand analysis and strategy tips.

Novel LLM usage: This isn’t just automating existing tasks - I’m using AI as both an exploration agent (to probe solver outputs) and as a writer (to explain complex concepts clearly). This combination creates content capabilities that didn’t exist before.

Transparent AI positioning: Brand myself as “Human + AI” poker analysis. Be upfront about using AI tools while emphasizing human judgment and experience.

Technical Priorities (Despite “No Product Development”)

I said I’d stop building features, but I need to fix the solver-LLM pipeline to eliminate hallucinations. The focus shifts from user-facing features to content creation tools:

  • Fix solver data output to provide complete strategic context
  • Build reliable solver-LLM pipeline for scalable content creation
  • Develop the infrastructure needed for consistent, accurate analysis

What’s Next

Weekly devlogs: Continue documenting discoveries and pivots transparently.

Manual hand analysis: Build audience and expertise through direct engagement while testing AI coach acceptance.

Content system development: Create the infrastructure for scalable marketing through AI-assisted content creation.

Eventual transition: Move from concierge to automated product once the core experience is proven and technical limitations are resolved.

Closing Reflection

Sometimes the best product development is realizing when to stop developing and start validating. This week taught me that building in public means being honest about failures, not just successes.

The forum experiment didn’t go as planned, but it revealed something more valuable than validation: it showed me exactly what needs to be fixed and where my assumptions were wrong. That’s worth more than a hundred positive feedback comments on a fundamentally flawed approach.

Next week: Testing how far I can push the LLM+solver integration to create a scalable marketing system. Building out the new website with proper landing page and CMS, then seeing what kind of poker content I can generate automatically.

Try the conversational expertise approach yourself at askpoker.ai, or contact me on Discord.
